p: Notably, the development of effective antiretroviral drugs (ARVs) has led to a significant reduction of AIDS-defining cancers (discussed below). In turn, the concomitant improvement of treated patientsâ€™ survival has doubled the number of people living with AIDS, and a large proportion of them is currently in the age range that is associated with augmented cancer risk [ 15]. As a consequence of an aging HIV-infected population, the occurrence of both HIV-associated (non-AIDS-defining) cancers and common incidental cancers has increased, becoming the main cause of death in developed countries [ 2]. It is noteworthy that adolescents and young adults living with AIDS also have an increased risk of developing both AIDS-defining and non-AIDS-defining cancers compared to HIV-negative individuals of the same age, and their relatively low adherence to ARVs could aggravate the occurrence of malignancies [ 16].
